Award.AwardTitle: Understanding PhD Career Pathways: Transitions and Persistence in the PhD-Prepared STEM Workforce
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Council of Graduate Schools will examine data about science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) PhD career aspirations and alumni outcomes from a network of 70 diverse U.S. doctoral institutions. The proposed project will conduct a survey to examine individual and environmental factors that influence retention and persistence in STEM careers and transitions between employment sectors. The underlying assumption of the project is that individual attributes such as self-efficacy and career values, as well as environmental factors such as organizational climate of the STEM workplace, could explain job transitions and persistence of early- and mid-career STEM doctorate holders. The project will contribute to knowledge about how these individual attributes and perceptions of environmental factors might change with various socialization, acculturation, and professionalization processes during and after the STEM doctoral education is completed. The project responds to recent studies that uncover declining interest in STEM academic careers and decreasing satisfaction with graduate school experiences by empirically documenting how socialization, acculturation, and professionalization activities may affect career progression in the STEM workforce. The project also isolates potential avenues for policy interventions designed to increase STEM persistence.

Grounded in career anchor and social cognitive career theory, the study will employ a mixed-methods design to investigate three research questions: (1) How do factors, including participation in various career and professional development activities, as well as prior employment as contingent faculty and/or postdoctoral trainee, explain persistence and transitions of STEM PhD alumni in the STEM professoriate or other STEM workplaces? (2) How do factors, including participation in various career and professional development activities, as well as prior/current employment as contingent faculty and/or postdoctoral trainee, explain perceptions about organizational climate and culture in STEM fields among doctoral scientists and engineers? and (3) How do individual factors, including participation in various career and professional development activities, as well as prior employment as contingent faculty and/or postdoctoral trainee, as well as perceptions about organizational climate and culture in STEM fields, influence career transitions of STEM PhD alumni and students across employment sectors in and out of STEM fields? Researchers will conduct a follow-up survey of more than 2,500 alumni and 4,000 student participants in the current Understanding PhD Career Pathways for Program Improvement in STEM project and include semi-structured qualitative interviews of a purposeful sample of survey respondents. Having collected the data, the researchers will run logistic regressions to determine which covariates are most informative for explaining STEM field persistence and transitions. The project will produce data that can guide investments and strategies to support STEM career development.

This project is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, STEM professional workforce development theme. ECR funds fundamental research projects that address STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Council of Graduate Schools (CGS) examined data about science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) PhD career aspirations and alumni outcomes from a network of diverse U.S. doctoral institutions. The goal of this project is to further the understanding of the career pathways of PhD holders in STEM fields and the implications for the administration of graduate education programs. Grounded in career anchor and social cognitive career theory, this project employed a mixed-methods design. Specifically, this project collected and analyzed detailed quantitative and qualitative data of STEM doctoral students and alumni at different phases of their careers. By studying STEM doctoral students at different phases of their careers, this project deepened our fundamental understanding of retention and persistence in STEM doctoral education and STEM careers. This project also interrogated what individual attributes and environmental factors of the STEM labor force impact persistence in STEM work and transitions between employment sectors, particularly among individuals from underrepresented backgrounds.

 

Over the course of this project, the CGS team carried out a number of activities to support the project goals. With support from the National Science Foundation (NSF award number 1661272), CGS has developed a network of 75 U.S. doctoral institutions collecting data about PhD career aspirations and PhD alumni outcomes. Using contact information provided by the baseline survey respondents who have agreed to be contacted for follow-up studies, the CGS team conducted a follow-up survey of more than 2,500 alumni and 4,000 student participants in the Understanding PhD Career Pathways for Program Improvement in STEM project. In addition, the CGS team conducted 80 semi-structured qualitative interviews of a purposeful sample of survey respondents using contact information gained through the baseline surveys. The interviewers were survey participants who had earned a PhD in STEM and who were underrepresented minorities in STEM.

The CGS team have publicly released findings through a series of data briefs, conference presentations and papers. Below is a summary of the significant results of this project:

 

Racial Climate. Among PhD students, perceptions of their program’s racial climate were positively linked to their overall program satisfaction. This finding provides evidence that climate is a salient factor in the STEM PhD experience and is the responsibility of faculty and program administrators.

 

PhD STEM Students of Color are Career Driven. PhD students of color in the STEM field are self-career driven and will research and apply for additional funding and fellowships, seek out supportive community, and pivot to overcome obstacles and maximize on career development and training opportunities.

 

Postdoctoral Experience. Not all postdocs subsequently went on to faculty positions. For postdocs in the STEM fields, a large percentage were working in industry. Former postdoctoral associates reported favorable views on how their postdoctoral experience helped them secure subsequent employment.

 

Timing Matters. Across many of the professional development activities surveyed, PhD alumni respondents noted that early professional development is essential for their perceptions of career preparation. Certain skills, such as networking, were rated as useful nearly equally across early, middle, and late doctoral programs.

 

Graduate institutions and scientific funders make significant investments in doctoral education to build the STEM workforce, and students themselves invest time and resources in pursuing STEM doctoral degrees. By providing new knowledge about the factors associated with STEM careers, this project would allow universities and scientific agencies to better deploy investments and strategies that support successful STEM career trajectories. By identifying factors associated with underrepresented minorities experience in the STEM professoriate, the project could help institutions refine their strategies for supporting graduate students and alumni pursuing careers in the STEM professoriate. The resulting findings will be added to the body of higher education research and scholarship on STEM doctoral education.

 


Last Modified: 09/09/2024
Modified by: Suzanne T Ortega
